DOC.HEAD: Coast Guard To Test New Tanker Tracking System
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Coast Guard says it will test a new system for keeping track of oil tankers in Alaska's Prince William Sound, site of the nation's worst oil spill. The system will utilize satellite signals and long-range aids to navigation rather than radar, said Mike Sollosi, chief of vessel traffic services in the Coast Guard's Washington, D.C., headquarters. ``It is a black box on a ship which takes an accurate position (of the vessel) and transmits the information to a vessel tracking system'' such as the vessel traffic center in Valdez, Sollosi said in a statement issued last week. He said a satellite is a tool for tracking ``because it is not affected by mountains, which is a problem in Alaska.'' Tanker traffic in Prince William Sound has been monitored by radar. But when the Exxon Valdez ran aground March 24, the Coast Guard said the vessel was beyond the area normally scanned by the Valdez radar. The ruptured tanker spilled 11 million gallons of crude oil into the sound. After the skipper reported the tanker was aground, the Coast Guard was able to find it on radar, but operators said reliability of the radar was limited by weather. Sollosi said the new system will be evaluated for one year in the sound and 22 other ports and waterways around the country. He said vessel owners will be responsible for the cost of installing the ``black boxes.''
